message.content:
cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.CE, cs.CR, cs.LO. 

This paper deals with the formal definition of actual causation, which is a fundamental concept in many different fields, such as legal theory, engineering, medicine, ethics, etc. The paper uses the formal language of CP-logic (Causal Probabilistic logic) to define actual causation and introduces a formal distinction between statistical and normative considerations. Therefore, the most likely sub-categories are cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) and cs.LG (Machine Learning), as these fields deal with probabilistic reasoning and causal inference. The sub-category cs.CE (Computational Engineering) is also likely, as it deals with the application of computational methods in engineering, which is one of the fields where actual causation is important. The sub-categories cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) and cs.LO (Logic in Computer Science) are less likely, but still possible, as they deal with formal reasoning and logic, which are also relevant to the paper's approach.
